facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 130 and 131 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 130 131 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from Madras High Court judgment dated December 3, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the Judgment and order dated December 3, 1963 of the Madras High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 380 of 1961 and 72 of 1962 respectively.

facts.text: Madras High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 380 of 1961 convicted appellant under s. 409 IPC and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought, by special leave, from the judgment of the Madras High Court dated December 3, 1963 in Criminal Appeal No. 380 of 1961 by which the appellant was convicted under s. 409, Indian Penal Code and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for one year.

facts.text: Appellant elected President of the Nerinjipet Panchayat Board on May 17, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was elected President of the Nerinjipet Panchayat Board on May 17, 1958. At that time he was a duly elected member of the Board.

facts.text: Rs. 4,000 of the Board invested in four National Plan Savings Certificates in Bhavani Post Office.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that a sum of Rs. 4,000 of the Board had been invested in four National Plan Savings Certificates in the Bhavani Post Office.

facts.text: Prosecution alleged appellant cashed the certificates on February 11, 1959 and did not bring the amount in the account books.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the appellant cashed them on February 11, 1959 and did number bring the amount in the account books of the Panchayat Board.

facts.text: Appellant handed endorsed certificates to P.W. 4, Deputy Panchayat Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellant was that he signed the certificates and handed them over to P.W. 4, the Deputy Panchayat Officer of the block within which the village was located.

facts.text: P.W. 4 got Rs. 500 in cash on December 2, 1958 from the Board.

anchor.surface_text: For that purpose P.W. 4 got Rs. 500 in cash on December 2, 1958 and a cheque for Rs. 2,500 on February 9, 1959.

facts.text: Board gave cheque for Rs. 2,500 to P.W. 4 on February 9, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: For that purpose P.W. 4 got Rs. 500 in cash on December 2, 1958 and a cheque for Rs. 2,500 on February 9, 1959.

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Erode acquitted the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Erode was number satisfied that the prosecution had proved the charge and therefore acquitted the appellant,

facts.text: Madras High Court on appeal convicted appellant, accepting prosecution evidence that appellant cashed the certificates.

anchor.surface_text: but on appeal the High Court accepted the prosecution evidence that it was the appellant who ,cashed the certificates at the Post Office and number P.W. 4 and accordingly found the appellant guilty of the offence.

facts.text: Sanction for prosecution given by Collector under s. 127 of Madras Village Panchayats Act.

anchor.surface_text: Sanction for the prosecution was, however, given in this case by the Collector and number by the Government under powers purported to have been delegated to him under s. 127 of the Madras Act

facts.text: Appellant argued that sanction by Government under s. 106 Madras Act was necessary.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was companytended that the sanction granted by the Collector was number valid in law and sanction should have been given under s. 106 of the Madras Act by the State Government.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that no sanction under s. 106 Madras Act necessary for prosecution under s. 409 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: for we companysider that numbersanction of the Government under s. 106 of the Madras Act is necessary for the prosecution of the appellant on the charge under s. 409, Indian Penal Code,

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 131 of 1964 from Madras High Court Criminal Appeal No. 72 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is brought, by special leave, from the judgment of the Madras High Court dated December 3, 1963 in Criminal Appeal No. 72 of 1962 companyvicting the appellant of the offence under s. 409,

facts.text: In CA 131/1964, appellant convicted under s. 409 IPC, sentenced to RI for 6 months.

anchor.surface_text: in Criminal Appeal No. 72 of 1962 companyvicting the appellant of the offence under s. 409, Indian Penal Code and sentencing him to rigorous imprisonment for 6 months.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed both appeals.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reject the argument of learned Counsel for the appellant on this aspect of the case and dismiss this appeal. ... This appeal also must be dismissed.

arguments.claim: Prosecution failed to prove that appellant cashed the certificates and misappropriated the proceeds; appellant handed endorsed certificates to P.W. 4 for reinvestment.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the appellant cashed them on February 11, 1959 and did number bring the amount in the account books of the Panchayat Board. The defence of the appellant was that he signed the certificates and handed them over to P.W. 4, the Deputy Panchayat Officer of the block within which the village was located. This was done by the appellant because W. 4 approached him and asked him that the Board should subscribe through him for small savings certificates for Rs. 7,000 just as the Panchayat had subscribed Rs. 7,000 through Tass liar representing the Revenue Department. For that purpose P.W. 4 got Rs. 500 in cash on December 2, 1958 and a cheque for Rs. 2,500 on February 9, 1959. It was the -case of the appellant that P.W. 4 represented that along with this SUM of Rs. 3,000 he would cash the National Plan Savings Certificates of the total value of Rs. 4,000 and purchase small savings ,certificates for Rs. 7,000

Emperor 1  was a decision of the Federal Court on the necessity for sanction under s. 270 of the Government of India Act, 1935, which is similar to s. 197 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure and S. 106 of the Madras Act.

arguments.claim: Same as in first appeal: no sanction under s.106 necessary for s.409 IPC.

holdings.text: no sanction of the Government under s. 106 of the Madras Act is necessary for the prosecution of the appellant on the charge under s. 409, Indian Penal Code, and the conviction of the appellant on that charge is not invalid on this account

anchor.surface_text: for we consider that no sanction of the Government under s. 106 of the Madras Act is necessary for the prosecution of the appellant on the charge under s. 409, Indian Penal Code, and the conviction of the appellant on that charge is not invalid on this account.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.106 similar to CrPC s.197; sanction required only for acts directly concerned with official duties claimable as done by virtue of office; s.409 misappropriation not such an act, official capacity relevant only to entrustment; following Hori Ram Singh v. Emperor, Gill v. King, Om Prakash Gupta v. State of UP, and other precedents

holdings.text: It is not therefore every offence committed by a public servant that requires sanction for prosecution under s. 197(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code nor even every act done by him while he is actually engaged in the performance of his official duties but if the act complained of is directly concerned with his official duties so that, if questioned, it could be claimed to have been done by virtue of the office, then sanction would be necessary

anchor.surface_text: It is not therefore every offence committed by a public servant that requires sanction for prosecution under s. 197(1) of the Criminal Procedure Code nor even every act done by him while he is actually engaged in the performance of his official duties but if the act complained of is directly concerned with his official duties so that, if questioned, it could be claimed to have been done by virtue of the office, then sanction would be necessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of test from Federal Court in Hori Ram Singh and Judicial Committee in Gill v. King: quality of act determines need for sanction; must lie within scope of official duty

holdings.text: sanction of the Government is not necessary for prosecution of the appellant under s. 409, Indian Penal Code and the conviction of the appellant on that charge is not defective in law

anchor.surface_text: The question of law involved in this appeal is the same as in Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1964 and for the reasons given in that case we hold that the sanction of the Government is not necessary for prosecution of the appellant under s. 409, Indian Penal Code and the conviction of the appellant on that charge is not defective in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same reasons as in CA 130/1964 applying official duty test to hold no sanction under s.106 needed for s.409

anchor.surface_text: Hori Rain Singh v. Emperor 1 was a decision of the Federal Court on the necessity for sanction under s. 270 of the Government of India Act, 1935, which is similar to s. 197 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure and S. 106 of the Madras Act. The facts in that case were that a Sub-Assistant Surgeon was charged under s. 409 with having dishonestly removed certain medicines from a hospital which was under his charge, to his own residence, and under s. 477-A, with having failed to enter them in the stock book.

precedents.cited_proposition: Sanction under s.270 Government of India Act not required for s.409 IPC as official capacity relevant only for entrustment, not misappropriation
precedents.cited_holding: no sanction was required for a charge under s. 409, because the official capacity is material only in connection with the entrustment and does not necessarily enter into the later act of misappropriation or conversion, which is the act complained of

anchor.surface_text: Gill v. The King 2  the question arose directly with reference to s. 197 i  of the Criminal Procedure Code. In that case the accused was charged under S. 161 with taking bribes, and under s. 120-B with conspiracy. On the question whether sanction was necessary under s. 197 1  it was held by the Judicial -Committee that there was nodifference in scope between that sanction and section 270 of the Government of India Act, 1935, and approving the statement of the law by Varadachariar, J. in Hori Ram Singh v. Emperor 1  Lord Simonds observed in the course of his judgment at page 40 of the Report In the consideration of s. 197 much assistance is to be derived from the judgment of the Federal Court in Hori Ram Singh v. The Crown  1939  F.C.R. 159, and in particular from the careful analysis of previous authorities which is to be found in the opinion of Varadachariar, J.

precedents.cited_proposition: No sanction under s.197 CrPC required if act not within scope of official duty; approves test from Hori Ram Singh
precedents.cited_holding: A public servant can only be said to act or to purport to act in the discharge of his official duty, if his act is such as to lie within the scope of his official duty

anchor.surface_text: Hori Ram Singh v. Emperor 1  Lord Simonds observed in the course of his judgment at page 40 of the Report In the consideration of s. 197 much assistance is to be derived from the judgment of the Federal Court in Hori Ram Singh v. The Crown  1939  F.C.R. 159, and in particular from the careful analysis of previous authorities which is to be found in the opinion of Varadachariar, J. Their Lordships, while admitting the convenience of the argument that in the circumstances prevailing in India a large measure of protection from harassing proceedings may be necessary for public officials, cannot accede to the view that the relevant words have the scope that has in some cases been given to them.

precedents.cited_proposition: Statement of law approved by Judicial Committee in Gill regarding scope of sanction requirement

precedents.citation: Hori Ram Singh v. The Crown  1939  F.C.R. 159

anchor.surface_text: Hori Ram Singh v. The Crown  1939  F.C.R. 159, and in particular from the careful analysis of previous authorities which is to be found in the opinion of Varadachariar, J. Their Lordships, while admitting the convenience of the argument that in the circumstances prevailing in India a large measure of protection from harassing proceedings may be necessary for public officials, cannot accede to the view that the relevant words have the scope that has in some cases been given to them. A public servant can only be said to act or to purport to act in the discharge of his official duty, if his act is such as to lie within the scope of his official duty. Thus a judge neither acts nor purports to act as a judge in receiving a bribe, though the judgment which he delivers may be such an act nor does a Government medical officer act or purport to act as a public servant in picking the pocket of a patient whom he is examining,  1  1939 F. C. R. 159.

precedents.case_name: Hori Ram Singh v. The Crown
precedents.cited_proposition: Assistance derived for consideration of s.197 CrPC; careful analysis of authorities

anchor.surface_text: Gill v. The King 1  was followed by the Judicial Committee in the later cases Albert West Meads v. The King 2  and Phanindra Chandra v. The King 3  and has been approved by this Court in R. W. Mathams v. State of west Bengal 4 . It is not therefore every offence committed by a public servant that requires sanction for prosecution under s. 197 1  of the Criminal Procedure Code nor even every act done by him while he is actually engaged in the performance of his official duties but if the act complained of is directly concerned with his official duties so that, if questioned, it could be claimed to have been done by virtue of the office, then sanction would be necessary.

precedents.cited_proposition: View on scope of sanction under s.197 CrPC followed in subsequent cases
precedents.cited_holding: no sanction under s. 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure was needed

precedents.citation: Albert West Meads v. The King 2

anchor.surface_text: Albert West Meads v. The King 2  and Phanindra Chandra v. The King 3  and has been approved by this Court in R. W. Mathams v. State of west Bengal 4 . It is not therefore every offence committed by a public servant that requires sanction for prosecution under s. 197 1  of the Criminal Procedure Code nor even every act done by him while he is actually engaged in the performance of his official duties but if the act complained of is directly concerned with his official duties so that, if questioned, it could be claimed to have been done by virtue of the office, then sanction would be necessary. It is the quality of the act that is important and if it falls within the scope and range of his official duties the protection contemplated by s. 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code will be attracted.

precedents.case_name: Albert West Meads v. The King
precedents.cited_proposition: Followed the view in Gill v. The King on sanction requirement

anchor.surface_text: Phanindra Chandra v. The King 3  and has been approved by this Court in R. W. Mathams v. State of west Bengal 4 . It is not therefore every offence committed by a public servant that requires sanction for prosecution under s. 197 1  of the Criminal Procedure Code nor even every act done by him while he is actually engaged in the performance of his official duties but if the act complained of is directly concerned with his official duties so that, if questioned, it could be claimed to have been done by virtue of the office, then sanction would be necessary. It is the quality of the act that is important and if it falls within the scope and range of his official duties the protection contemplated by s. 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code will be attracted. An offence may be entirely unconnected with the official duty as such or it may be committed within the scope of the official duty.

precedents.cited_proposition: Followed the view in Gill v. The King on sanction requirement

precedents.citation: R. W. Mathams v. State of west Bengal 4

anchor.surface_text: R. W. Mathams v. State of west Bengal 4 . It is not therefore every offence committed by a public servant that requires sanction for prosecution under s. 197 1  of the Criminal Procedure Code nor even every act done by him while he is actually engaged in the performance of his official duties but if the act complained of is directly concerned with his official duties so that, if questioned, it could be claimed to have been done by virtue of the office, then sanction would be necessary. It is the quality of the act that is important and if it falls within the scope and range of his official duties the protection contemplated by s. 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code will be attracted. An offence may be entirely unconnected with the official duty as such or it may be committed within the scope of the official duty. Where it is unconnected with the official duty there can be no protection.

precedents.case_name: R.W. Mathams v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Approved the view in Gill v. The King on sanction requirement

precedents.citation: Om Prakash Gupta v. State of U.P.  5

anchor.surface_text: Om Prakash Gupta v. State of U.P.  5  in which it was pointed out that sanction to the prosecution of a public servant under S. 409 of the Indian Penal Code is not necessary since the public servant is not acting in his official capacity in committing criminal breach of trust. In a later case--Satwant Singh v. The State of Punjab 6 , it was held that if a public servant commits the offence of cheating or abets another so to cheat, the offence committed by him is not one while he is acting or purporting to act in the discharge of his official duty. The same view his been taken by this Court in a later decision-Baijnath Gupta and Ors. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 7 , and it was held that the sanction of the State Government was not necessary for the prosecution of  1  1948 F.C.R. 19.

precedents.case_name: Om Prakash Gupta v. State of U.P.
precedents.cited_proposition: Sanction not necessary for prosecution under s.409 IPC as public servant not acting in official capacity
precedents.cited_holding: sanction to the prosecution of a public servant under S. 409 of the Indian Penal Code is not necessary since the public servant is not acting in his official capacity in committing criminal breach of trust

precedents.citation: Satwant Singh v. The State of Punjab 6

anchor.surface_text: Satwant Singh v. The State of Punjab 6 , it was held that if a public servant commits the offence of cheating or abets another so to cheat, the offence committed by him is not one while he is acting or purporting to act in the discharge of his official duty. The same view his been taken by this Court in a later decision-Baijnath Gupta and Ors. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 7 , and it was held that the sanction of the State Government was not necessary for the prosecution of the appellant under s. 409 of the Indian Penal Code because the act of criminal misappropriation was not committed by the appellant while he was acting or purporting to act in discharge of his official duties and that offence had no direct connection with the duties of the appellant as a public servant, and the official status of the appellant only furnished the appellant with an occasion or an oppor- tunity of committing the offence.

precedents.case_name: Satwant Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Offence of cheating by public servant or abetment not in discharge of official duty, no sanction needed
precedents.cited_holding: if a public servant commits the offence of cheating or abets another so to cheat, the offence committed by him is not one while he is acting or purporting to act in the discharge of his official duty

precedents.citation: Baijnath Gupta and Ors. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 7

anchor.surface_text: Baijnath Gupta and Ors. v. The State of Madhya Pradesh 7 , and it was held that the sanction of the State Government was not necessary for the prosecution of the appellant under s. 409 of the Indian Penal Code because the act of criminal misappropriation was not committed by the appellant while he was acting or purporting to act in discharge of his official duties and that offence had no direct connection with the duties of the appellant as a public servant, and the official status of the appellant only furnished the appellant with an occasion or an oppor- tunity of committing the offence. Section 106 of the Madras Act is similar in language to s. 197 of the Criminal Procedure Code and for the reasons already expressed we are of the opinion that the sanction of the State Government was not necessary for prosecution of the appellant under S. 409, Indian Penal Code.

precedents.case_name: Baijnath Gupta v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: No sanction needed for s.409 IPC as misappropriation not in discharge of official duties; official status only provides opportunity
precedents.cited_holding: the sanction of the State Government was not necessary for the prosecution of the appellant under s. 409 of the Indian Penal Code because the act of criminal misappropriation was not committed by the appellant while he was acting or purporting to act in discharge of his official duties

justification_sets.label: Section 106 Madras Village Panchayats Act support

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reject the argument of learned Counsel for the appellant on this aspect of the case and dismiss this appeal.

outcome.relief_summary: Criminal Appeals Nos. 130 and 131 of 1964 dismissed. No sanction under s.106 of the Madras Village Panchayats Act required for prosecution under s.409 IPC; convictions upheld.

Concept c4 provides the general test for when s.197 sanction is required (acts concerned with official duties), grounding the holding h1 that no sanction needed as act not qualifying.

The unlisted official duty test (c5) is applied to conclude that criminal misappropriation under s.409 does not fall within the scope of official duties requiring sanction, thereby grounding the holding h1 that no sanction is necessary.

anchor.surface_text: for we consider that no sanction of the Government under s. 106 of the Madras Act is necessary for the prosecution of the appellant on the charge under s. 409, Indian Penal Code, and the conviction of the appellant on that charge is not invalid on this account.
We accordingly reject the argument of learned Counsel for the appellant on this aspect of the case and dismiss this appeal.
We accordingly reject the argument of learned Counsel for the appellant on this aspect of the case and dismiss this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The question of law involved in this appeal is the same as in Criminal Appeal No. 130 of 1964 and for the reasons given in that case we hold that the sanction of the Government is not necessary for prosecution of the appellant under s. 409, Indian Penal Code and the conviction of the appellant on that charge is not defective in law.
We accordingly reject the argument of learned Counsel for the appellant on this aspect of the case and dismiss this appeal.
